text: There are a lot of unknowns around exactly how virtualisation is done with regards e.g. rounding of liquidity. I'm talking about being able to take an unvirtualised market book and produce the virtualised market book that exactly matches what is in the virtual price stream. This is the best I got to: <https://github.com/mberk/betfairutil/compare/master...virtualisation>

elements.text: There are a lot of unknowns around exactly how virtualisation is done with regards e.g. rounding of liquidity. text: By the way, here is the calculation (taken from an old betfair doc, most of which is out of date now)...See Page 24

text:
I know how the XM and XMXM code works in detail (I wrote it and designed the algos and numerical solvers). I'll be at the next meetup if anyone needs some details albeit I probably can't remember everything. FWIW the "150ms" lag on the virtual pricing is just an SLA as I needed some time do the calcs and I didn't want to delay the raw stream (so as to publish in sync) as I was concerned that would disrupt all market dynamics and destroy everything...

Also note that some behaviours appear non-deterministic when viewed externally as they will be related to global bet manipulation load, depth of market and probabilistic polynomial solve times which means sometimes it has to give up (non issue with XM). This only applies to pricing, matching always completes as it operates at inconsequential load compared to pricing.

elements.text:

text: guaranteed in what sense? The virtualisation servers attempt to spend no longer than about 150ms (Betfair can configure this) on the work but the length of time to do the work is not predictable before they start. I'm sure in reality it drifts in and out, under light load you may find it is negligible.

elements.text: guaranteed in what sense? The virtualisation servers attempt to spend no longer than about 150ms (Betfair can configure this) on the work but the length of time to do the work is not predictable before they start. I'm sure in reality it drifts in and out, under light load you may find it is negligible.

text: Also there is no guarantee you will see the lag in your stream messages, that depends when they get sent out which depends on load, your current tcp queue depth, etc.

elements.text: Also there is no guarantee you will see the lag in your stream messages, that depends when they get sent out which depends on load, your current tcp queue depth, etc.

text: Will a reply from me do?

text: of course please?

elements.text: of course please?

text: Ok - so do you get the basic concept of cross matching?

elements.text: Ok - so do you get the basic concept of cross matching?

text: I think so, Betfair want to match more prices by creating virtual bets on the opposite side at other prices...?

elements.text: I think so, Betfair want to match more prices by creating virtual bets on the opposite side at other prices...?

text: Take the simplest case - a tennis match. You've got someone who wants to back player A at 2, since laying player A and backing player B are effectively the same thing Betfair can display the person's back bet both as being available as a Lay on player A, and available as a back on player B. The available to back bet that you see on player B is described as "virtual" and the process of calculating and displaying those "virtual" bets is "virtualisation".

elements.text: Take the simplest case - a tennis match. You've got someone who wants to back player A at 2, since laying player A and backing player B are effectively the same thing Betfair can display the person's back bet both as being available as a Lay on player A, and available as a back on player B. The available to back bet that you see on player B is described as "virtual" and the process of calculating and displaying those "virtual" bets is "virtualisation".

text:
So I'm going to admit that I don't do "proper" regression. I just plot my features, look at the plots, rub my face, think about it, make up something plausible and try it.

Every once in a while I get all anxious that I should have done it properly, so I make a big effort and do xgboost or whatever, then I test that against my "eyeball" criteria and either the eyeball wins or the difference is trivial.

My general experience is that there are huge gains to be found when I find a new feature but overly stressing on the model doesn't yield much.

elements.text:
So I'm going to admit that I don't do "proper" regression. I just plot my features, look at the plots, rub my face, think about it, make up something plausible and try it.

Every once in a while I get all anxious that I should have done it properly, so I make a big effort and do xgboost or whatever, then I test that against my "eyeball" criteria and either the eyeball wins or the difference is trivial.

My general experience is that there are huge gains to be found when I find a new feature but overly stressing on the model doesn't yield much.

text:
I personally use certain methods of good old fashioned classical inference.
As for why:
1. I don't like using any methods that I DON'T understand from a theoretical standpoint. This rules out most ML at this point in time (even though things like logistic regression seem to be labelled as ML nowadays, to me it's just a GLM).
2. I like to use models where parameters are evaluated and known as part of the model fitting process (I don't like black boxes). This allows some kind of common sense validation and quantification of parameter effects.
3. I use C++ so I need to be able to evaluate models in that context - not by plugging data into some black box evaluation package in python or R. This reason is wrapped up with 2 to a certain extent.
It might make me a bit of a dinosaur, but I'm a firm believer that statistics can be (and is) abused and is most useful when you understand what it's doing. Never been a fan of throwing a shitload of data into a black box and using the output despite having no idea what is going on under the surface.

elements.text:
I personally use certain methods of good old fashioned classical inference.
As for why:

I don't like using any methods that I DON'T understand from a theoretical standpoint. This rules out most ML at this point in time (even though things like logistic regression seem to be labelled as ML nowadays, to me it's just a GLM).

I like to use models where parameters are evaluated and known as part of the model fitting process (I don't like black boxes). This allows some kind of common sense validation and quantification of parameter effects.
I use C++ so I need to be able to evaluate models in that context - not by plugging data into some black box evaluation package in python or R. This reason is wrapped up with 2 to a certain extent.

It might make me a bit of a dinosaur, but I'm a firm believer that statistics can be (and is) abused and is most useful when you understand what it's doing. Never been a fan of throwing a shitload of data into a black box and using the output despite having no idea what is going on under the surface.

text: I use C++ too, many of the machine learning packages are written in a systems programming language and expose a C API, you don’t have to use Python or R.

elements.text: I use C++ too, many of the machine learning packages are written in a systems programming language and expose a C API, you don’t have to use Python or R.
